channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Nantes: Arson suspected in fire at Saint-Pierre-et-Saint-Paul cathedral
item.description: Prosecutors say three fires were started at the site, and are treating the blaze as a criminal act.

item.title: John Lewis: Civil rights icon and congressman dies aged 80
item.description: Lewis, who was the last of the Big Six civil rights leaders, was diagnosed with cancer in December.

item.title: Aishwarya Rai Bachchan: Indian actress taken to hospital with Covid-19
item.description: The Indian actress and her daughter had been isolating since testing positive earlier this week.

item.title: Sergei Furgal: Fresh protests in Khabarovsk over governor's arrest
item.description: Demonstrators say they are taking to the streets "because our governor was stolen from us".

item.title: Iran sends black box of Ukrainian plane to France
item.description: Iran says the plane, which had 176 people on board, was mistaken for a cruise missile.

item.title: Coronavirus: US v other countries... did it mess up its reopening?
item.description: By the time most Americans emerged from lockdown restrictions, a second surge was already under way.

item.title: Twitter says hackers downloaded private account data
item.description: It says attackers copied records from up to eight hacked users, but none were "blue tick" accounts.

item.title: Portland protests: Federal agents 'abuse power' in arrests
item.description: Men wearing camouflage and driving unmarked cars grabbed demonstrators without explanation.

item.title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg: Supreme court justice will not retire after cancer diagnosis
item.description: The court's most senior liberal justice has a recurrence of cancer and is undergoing chemotherapy.

item.title: World faces staggering jobs challenge, says Microsoft president
item.description: A quarter of a billion people are set to lose their job this year, Microsoft's president tells the BBC.

item.title: Amazon soya and beef exports 'linked to deforestation'
item.description: UK consumers may unwittingly be buying meat linked to the destruction of the Amazon, experts say.

item.title: US cars 'must be left out of post-Brexit trade deal'
item.description: UK safety campaigners raise concerns about an increase in the number of US deaths caused by SUVs.

item.title: Unflustered news anchor loses tooth live on air
item.description: Marichka Padalko simply put the tooth in her hand and continued presenting the news.

item.title: Week in pictures: 11-17 July 2020
item.description: A selection of powerful news photographs taken around the world this week.

item.title: Why I fell in love with Irish dancing
item.description: Morgan Bullock was accused of "cultural appropriation" after a video of her Irish dancing went viral.

item.title: Social media influencers warned against promoting fake brands
item.description: Trading Standards and police are warning social media influencers against promoting fake brands.

item.title: Beetle-mounted camera streams insect adventures
item.description: Researchers have developed a tiny lightweight video camera that can be carried by a beetle.

item.title: Solar Orbiter: Closest ever pictures taken of the Sun
item.description: The European Solar Orbiter probe captures images just 77 million km from the Sun's surface.

item.title: In pictures: Severe floods engulf eastern China
item.description: Water levels at Poyang lake, in China's eastern Jiangxi province, are at a record high.

item.title: Quiz of the week: Which Chicken Run star was 'plucked and stuffed'?
item.description: How closely have you been paying attention to what's been going on during the past seven days?

item.title: The Simpsons: The black actor hoping his impressions get him a job
item.description: Jayden Libran has had loads of support on Simpsons fan sites - but is it enough to get him a job?

item.title: Obituary: Civil rights champion John Lewis
item.description: John Lewis forged his legacy as a champion for civil rights and racial equality in the 1960s.

item.title: Jeyaraj and Benicks: Why was a viral video on custodial deaths taken down?
item.description: Suchitra Ramadurai's Instagram video catapulted a case nationally - then disappeared from the internet.

item.title: Coronavirus tests: Swabs don't damage the brain and other claims fact-checked
item.description: False rumours that coronavirus tests can be harmful have circulated in several different languages.

item.title: How a Colombian market is using AI to combat Covid-19 outbreaks
item.description: Markets have been virus hotspots in Colombia, so one of them is trying a new way to curb the spread.

item.title: Could Canada's worst mass shooting have been avoided?
item.description: Questions still remain three months after Gabriel Wortman went on a rampage across Nova Scotia.

item.title: My Money: 'My house looks happy'
item.description: Anna Josse Eklund from Sweden takes us through her week during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: In pictures: How coronavirus swept through Brazil
item.description: As the country passes 2m cases, we tell the story of how the outbreak spread in pictures.

item.title: Sergei Furgal: The arrest fuelling anti-Moscow anger in Russia's far east
item.description: Thousands have been rallying in Khabarovsk to demand their governor be returned for a fair trial.

item.title: Doctor Room: The counsellor helping digital sex crime victims
item.description: "I felt that taking a break is a sin," she says. "If I sleep it means more videos get out there."

item.title: Lewis Hamilton on Hungarian Grand Prix pole position
item.description: Lewis Hamilton beats team-mate Valtteri Bottas to lead a Mercedes one-two in qualifying for the Hungarian Grand Prix.

item.title: England v West Indies: Rain wipes out day three of second Test
item.description: England face a race against time to level the series against West Indies after the third day of the second Test is washed out.

item.title: Woods makes cut as DeChambeau has a quintuple-bogey 10 at Memorial
item.description: Tiger Woods' record of never missing the cut at the Memorial Tournament is extended but Bryson DeChambeau has a quintuple-bogey 10 and will not play the weekend.

item.title: Man Utd without injured Shaw for FA Cup semi-final against Chelsea
item.description: Preview followed by live coverage of Sunday's FA Cup semi-final between Manchester United and Chelsea.

item.title: Wounds of Dutch history expose deep racial divide
item.description: Faced with protests and attacks on statues, the Dutch are struggling with a legacy of racism.

item.title: The perfume makers that can't smell a thing
item.description: Perfumers are using AI to create millions of scents, but will it replace the traditional methods?

item.title: Egypt desperate to revive coronavirus-hit tourism industry
item.description: The pandemic brought Egypt's tourism industry to a virtual halt, affecting millions of livelihoods.

item.title: Coronavirus: ‘Lego helped me get out of bed’
item.description: Charlotte Tyrer, 25, makes portraits of celebrities to keep herself busy during lockdown.

item.title: Seven countries with big (and small) population problems
item.description: A look at seven countries facing dramatic population changes - and how they are tackling the problem.

item.title: Letters of love: 'Our father wrote every day as he waited to be sent to Auschwitz'
item.description: Daniele Israel's daily letters to his family from jail in Trieste paint a moving portrait of a family shattered by the Holocaust.
